0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-ryan-idUSKBN13A2J7	House Speaker Paul Ryan renominated to top House post	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republicans in the U.S. House of Representatives nominated Speaker Paul Ryan on Tuesday for re-election to his post next year
column2: as lawmakers giddy with election success smoothed over their differences and pledged to unite behind Republican President-elect Donald Trump.Ryan
column3: who faced no challengers from Republican ranks
column4: was nominated in a unanimous voice vote in a closed-door meeting of all Republican lawmakers in the House. He will face an election in January
column5: when all members of the new House
column6: both majority Republicans and minority Democrats
column7: vote on a new speaker.While January's outcome is not guaranteed
column8: Republicans who had been feuding with each other and Trump before the election said Tuesday they thought Ryan was in a solid position to be re-elected speaker now that intra-party tensions have dramatically lessened with the Republican election victory.""Politics is politics
column9: but this is as unified as I've ever seen it
column10: said New York Republican Representative Peter King
column11: who has been in Congress since 1993.Republicans kept their majorities in both the House and Senate in the Nov. 8 elections in which voters elected Trump to the White House over Democrat Hillary Clinton.

column1: Ryan
column3: had criticized Trump numerous times during the campaign
column4: which angered some of Trump's supporters in the Republican caucus. Had Trump lost the election
column5: these Republicans and some conservatives who already had doubts about Ryan might have sought to blame him and block his re-election.But lawmakers said Trump's election
column6: along with a stronger-than-expected performance at the polls by House Republicans

column1: To suggest that President-elect Trump's victory didn't weigh as a factor in terms of the speaker's race would be disingenuous"" said Representative Mark Meadows
column2: a member of the conservative Freedom Caucus.However
column3: one conservative lawmaker
column4: Representative Raul Labrador
column5: continued to express skepticism about Ryan ahead of Tuesday's vote
column6: and said he would not consider Tuesday's outcome binding on his vote in January.""I haven't heard from him what he wants to change -- what's going to be different the next two years than the last two years?"" Labrador asked reporters.

column1: Ryan
column2: for his part
column3: said House Republicans would be working ""hand in glove"" with Trump. ""We're going to do everything we can to help him be as successful as he can
column4: Ryan told reporters ahead of Tuesday's vote.Republicans also re-elected three other lawmakers to leadership positions: House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy
column5: House Republican Whip Steve Scalise
column6: and the chairwoman of the Republican conference
column7: Cathy McMorris Rodgers. (Additional reporting by Susan Heavey and Doina Chiacu; Editing by Lisa Shumaker and James Dalgleish)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-sec-congress-idUSKBN13A2TO	Republicans to U.S. securities regulator: Leave new rules to Trump	"
By Lisa Lambert
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republican lawmakers told the top U.S. securities regulator on Tuesday they are concerned her agency will rush out new rules in the final weeks that President Barack Obama
column2: a Democrat
column3: holds the Oval Office.The chair of the House Financial Services Committee
column4: Jeb Hensarling
column5: who has been mentioned as a possible Treasury secretary under Republican President-elect Donald Trump
column6: said ""whenever there is a transfer of power from one presidential administration to another
column7: there is a temptation for federal agencies to rush pending rulemakings to completion
column8: as a way of cementing the policy priorities of the outgoing administration.""""I would strongly urge you to respect the results of last week's election and resist the temptation to finalize any regulations
column10: added Hensarling during a hearing on the Securities and Exchange Commission.SEC Chair Mary Jo White was the hearing's sole witness. On Monday she announced she will leave her post when Obama's term ends in January
column11: a decision made before Trump's stunning election win.She told the committee firmly there would be no surprise rulemakings or ramming pending rules through to completion. ""I don't see any last-minute rushes. I do intend to carry out the agenda I outlined in February 2016 as much as I can

column1: I don't think any rulemaking benefits from it being rushed. It's hard to do it right
column2: she also said. Nonetheless
column3: White would not commit when asked about a proposed multi-agency rule for clawing back compensation from executives who have committed wrongdoing.The SEC and fellow major financial regulators must approve the rule for it to become final
column4: and the lawmakers pressed White to not bring it up for a commission vote while she is still chair.

column1: White said she could not predict what will happen in the next 2-1/2 months
column2: or what will be included in the final draft of the rule.To continue carrying out its agenda announced earlier this year
column3: the SEC will focus on capital segregation rules
column4: an outstanding derivatives rule
column5: and a staff recommendation on mutual fund disclosure
column6: White said.The 2010 Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform law is considered one of Obama's signature domestic achievements
column7: and federal agencies have furiously put in place new regulations and systems to carry out its many moving parts.

column1: Trump has said he would repeal parts of the law
column2: and he is expected to use legislation Hensarling drafted as a blueprint for his plans.Only half a dozen Democrats attended Tuesday's hearing
column3: primarily asking about corporate board diversity and the Wells Fargo ghost account scandal
column4: or blasting Trump.White
column5: an independent
column6: has been criticized by both parties. Democrat Senator Elizabeth Warren recently called on Obama to fire her
column7: and progressives say she slowed down implementing Dodd-Frank. White said the SEC has completed 80 percent of the rulemakings required by Dodd-Frank. She added that she would not want to see parts of the law
column8: including the Volcker rule restricting banks from making speculative investments
column9: rescinded in the future. (Reporting by Lisa Lambert)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-staff-idUSKBN13A2B8	Trump eyeing Mnuchin and Ross for economy jobs: Icahn	"
By Jennifer Ablan and David Lawder
| NEW YORK/WASHINGTON

NEW YORK/WASHINGTON Longtime Donald Trump supporter and activist investor Carl Icahn confirmed on Tuesday that the president-elect is looking at Wall Street veteran Steven Mnuchin as his choice for treasury secretary and billionaire Wilbur Ross for commerce secretary. ""Spoke to @realDonaldTrump. Steve Mnuchin and Wilbur Ross are being considered for Treasury and Commerce. Both would be great choices
column2: Icahn wrote on Twitter. Icahn
column3: a close ally of Trump who was often praised by the Republican during the presidential campaign for his business acumen
column4: also tweeted that both Mnuchin and Ross were friends and ""two of the smartest people I know.""Mnuchin
column5: a former Goldman Sachs partner and Trump's campaign finance manager
column6: has been considered a front-runner for the Treasury post for much of the past week since Trump's stunning election victory.Mnuchin's inclusion in Trump's campaign team was questioned at the time by Stephen Bannon
column7: now Trump's chief White House strategist. In an interview on Breitbart News
column8: Bannon asked Trump whether the then presidential candidate was ""selling out to Wall Street"". The list to head the Treasury Department has also included JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon and Republican Representative Jeb Hensarling
column9: chairman of the powerful House Financial Services Committee. Hensarling has said he would prefer to focus on a revamp of financial regulation
column12: has denied interest in the job in the past.        Ross
column14: is a part of Trump's economic advisory team. Calls to Ross were not immediately returned.

column1: INTO THE TOWER
Mnuchin walked through the Trump Tower lobby in Manhattan on Tuesday morning. He would not comment on personnel decisions but said the Trump team is ""making sure we get the biggest tax bill passed
column2: the biggest tax changes since Reagan. So a lot of exciting things in the first 100 days of the Trump presidency.""With Republicans retaining majorities in Congress
column3: Trump will have a clearer shot at enacting major tax cut and reform legislation and rolling back the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial regulation law passed in the wake of the financial crisis.

column1: The new treasury secretary would play a key role in crafting such legislation
column2: as well as managing potential new debt issuance of as much as $1 trillion if Congress agrees to Trump's proposed infrastructure spending program.With such high stakes
column3: Wall Street is more focused on the selection of the next treasury chief than it was during President Barack Obama's choices for the post.""This time will be different
column4: Gregory Peters
column5: senior investment officer at Prudential Fixed Income
column6: said Tuesday at the Reuters Global Investment Outlook Summit in New York. ""That role takes on greater importance.""

column1: Unlike current Secretary Jacob Lew
column2: who is viewed investors to have taken a lower profile focused largely on international issues over the past year
column3: the next Treasury secretary is expected to be a featured player in articulating and executing the Trump administration's new economic policies and initiatives.    A figure such as Mnuchin
column4: with Wall Street experience
column5: might be seen as better equipped to manage the relationship between Treasury and the banks that facilitate U.S. debt issuance. The last Wall Street insider to serve in the post was Henry Paulson
column6: the former Goldman Sachs CEO appointed by George W. Bush and whose term was dominated by the bank bailouts of the 2008 financial crisis.Mnuchin
column7: whose father was also a Goldman Sachs partner
column8: worked at the investment bank for nearly two decades starting in the mid-1980s
column9: a time when Wall Street was developing major financial innovations including new securitization techniques and collateralized debt obligations -- instruments that would later contribute to the financial crisis.In 2009
column10: he led a group of investors that purchased the assets of failed California-based mortgage lender IndyMac
column11: for $1.55 billion that included a loss-sharing deal with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. After rehabilitating the operation and rebranding it as OneWest Bank
column12: they sold it in 2014 for $3.4 billion to CIT Group Inc for $3.4 billion. (Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson and Richard Leong in New York; Editing by David Chance and Alistair Bell)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-steyer-idUSKBN13A2RN	Exclusive: Billionaire green activist Steyer vows to battle Trump
column2: says money not an issue	"

column1: By Richard Valdmanis
| BOSTON
BOSTON Billionaire environmental activist Tom Steyer
column2: who has spent more than $140 million on fighting climate change
column3: said on Tuesday he will spend whatever it takes to fight President-elect Donald Trump's pro-drilling and anti-regulation agenda.The former hedge fund manager from California is putting together a strategy that will ""engage voters and citizens to fight back"" once Trump takes the White House in January
column4: he told Reuters in an interview. However
column5: he stressed he was not planning to fight Trump through the courts.Instead
column6: he would focus on ""trying to present an opposite point of view and trying to get that point of view expressed
column7: and communicated to citizens.""Steyer's pledge to fight Trump suggests an intensifying battle for U.S. public opinion on global climate change
column8: an issue that has already divided many Americans
column10: and companies between those who consider it a major global threat and those who doubt its existence.Other U.S. environmental groups are also preparing to resist Trump's agenda
column11: with some vowing street protests and more established organizations that helped draft some of President Barack Obama's environmental regulations preparing to defend them in court.""We have always been willing to do whatever is necessary
column13: when asked how much money he was willing to spend to oppose Trump's agenda.Trump campaigned on a promise to drastically reduce environmental regulation and ease permitting for infrastructure
column14: moves he said would breathe life into an oil and gas industry ailing from low prices
column15: without harming U.S. air and water quality.

column1: He has also called climate change a hoax and has promised to ""cancel"" the Paris Climate Accord between nearly 200 nations to slow global warming
column2: a deal he said would cost the U.S. economy trillions of dollars and put it at a disadvantage.While the approach has cheered the industry
column3: it has sent shockwaves through the environmental movement
column4: which is confronting the prospect of losing all progress it made during the Obama administration.Steyer
column5: who had endorsed Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton
column6: called Trump's policies dangerous.""Every single one of these things
column7: whether it was getting rid of Paris or cutting back the EPA
column8: we think are extremely dangerous to the security of every American
column9: Steyer said. ""We think it is based on willful ignorance of the facts and flies in the face of the realities facing the world.""

column1: ARCTIC DRILLING
Steyer's main political vehicle
column2: NextGen Climate
column3: on Tuesday called on the Obama administration to defy Trump's pro-drilling agenda by issuing an order permanently blocking all new drilling in the Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

column1: Trump has also promised to ask Canadian oil pipeline company
column2: TransCanada Corp
column3: to resubmit its application to build a pipeline into the United States that would link Alberta's vast oil sands to American refineries and ports on the Gulf Coast. The project
column4: Keystone XL
column5: had been rejected by the Obama administration after years of mass protests and lobbying by environmental organizations.Steyer said the project may no longer make sense since a slump in oil prices has reduced the profitability of oil sands production.Steyer
column6: who four years ago left the hedge fund firm he co-founded to devote himself full-time to environmental activism
column7: said young voter turnout in areas where NextGen focused its mobilization efforts during the 2016 campaign was up more than 20 percent from the last presidential election in 2012.""Did we get the president we want
column8: absolutely not. Did we get a majority of clean energy supporters in the senate
column10: Steyer said. ""But in terms of what we did
column12: we wouldn't do anything differently."" NextGen poured nearly $69 million into its elections related programs during the presidential campaign
column13: according to federal records compiled by OpenSecrets.org
column14: slightly lower than the $74 million it spent during the mid-term congressional elections in 2014
column15: when only two of the six candidates it supported won.  (Reporting by Richard Valdmanis

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-iraq-idUSKBN13A01D	Trump could return Iraq war boosters to power	"
By Warren Strobel and John Walcott
(Corrects this Nov. 14 to clarify details of Bolton's recess appointment
column2: paragraph 8.)By Warren Strobel and John WalcottWASHINGTON Despite his professed opposition to the 2003 U.S. invasion of Iraq
column3: President-elect Donald Trump is considering several of the major advocates of that war for top national security posts in his administration
column4: according to Republican officials.Among those who could find places on Trump's team are former top State Department official John Bolton and ex-CIA Director James Woolsey. Both men championed the Iraq invasion
column5: which many analysts have called one of the major U.S. foreign policy debacles of modern times.Also involved in transition planning for Trump's presidency is Frederick Fleitz
column6: a top aide to Bolton who earlier worked at the CIA unit that validated much of the flawed intelligence on Iraq's weapons of mass destruction programs.Although it is impossible to predict how a Trump foreign policy might evolve
column7: one U.S. official who has served in Iraq said advocates of the 2003 invasion might be more inclined to commit additional U.S. forces to the fight against Islamic State there
column8: despite the absence of a status of forces agreement that protects Americans from Iraqi legal action.Paul Pillar
column9: the top U.S. intelligence official for the Near East from 2000 to 2005
column10: said that because Trump had little foreign policy experience and had given conflicting accounts of what policies he would pursue
column11: the Republican president-elect's senior personnel appointments would be crucial.""What we're seeing going on - and we should be worried about it - is a new president who on so many foreign policy issues has been all over the map
column14: the senior appointments game that we go through every four years has more consequences than it usually does.""

column1: Bolton
column2: who is under consideration as Trump's secretary of state
column3: the officials said
column4: and Woolsey
column5: reported to be in the running for U.S. director of national intelligence
column6: did not respond to requests for comment. The Trump transition team also did not immediately respond when asked for comment.Even if Bolton is nominated
column7: Senate confirmation is not a foregone conclusion. In 2005
column8: Senate Democrats - with the support of a single Republican - blocked a vote to confirm him as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations. He was appointed to that post by Republican President George W. Bush while the Senate was in recess.NEOCONSERVATIVE REVIVAL?

column1: Fleitz
column2: in a brief phone conversation
column3: confirmed he was involved in Trump's transition effort
column4: but declined further comment. A return to power for the three officials would represent a change of fortune for them and other ""neoconservatives"" who provided the intellectual backing for the invasion of Iraq. During the presidential campaign
column5: some leading neoconservatives and Republican foreign policy veterans opposed Trump
column6: saying he was unfit to lead.The group saw its clout wane in Bush's second term
column7: as U.S. troops in Iraq found themselves mired in a sectarian civil war
column8: and has watched from the sidelines during Democratic President Barack Obama's eight years in power.Trump
column10: has said he opposed the invasion of Iraq
column12: 000 U.S. troops and hundreds of thousands of Iraqis died
column13: and which led to the creation of al Qaeda in Iraq

column1: Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction and ties to al Qaeda
column2: used to justify the invasion
column3: proved to be nonexistent. ""As you know
column4: for years I've been saying: 'Don't go into Iraq.' They went into Iraq. They destabilized the Middle East. It was a big mistake
column5: Trump said in August 2015 on NBC's ""Meet the Press"" program.His account that he always opposed the war was challenged during the campaign by Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column6: who cited a 2002 interview Trump gave to radio host Howard Stern in which he replied: ""Yeah I guess so"" when asked if he supported invading Iraq.Consideration of Bolton
column7: Woolsey and others is ""another demonstration of how those who supported one of the biggest mistakes in American foreign policy have not been - they don't seem to be sufficiently discredited to be removed from the Washington foreign policy dialogue
column8: Pillar said. (Additional reporting by Mark Hosenball
column10: Jonathan Landay and Doina Chiacu; editing by Yara Bayoumy and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-york-postits-idUSKBN13A2IV	New Yorkers build walls of sticky notes in defiance of Trump	"
By David Ingram
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK This is not the kind of wall Donald Trump was talking about.In the liberal stronghold of New York City
column2: residents distraught over the incoming Republican administration were finding solace a week after the U.S. presidential election by placing handwritten
column3: anonymous notes on the walls of a busy subway station.On Tuesday
column4: many notes offered support to immigrants or mocked Trump's promise to build a wall along the United States-Mexico border and have Mexico pay for it.""A better wall
column5: read one sticky note.""This is the wall that love can build
column6: read another. Titled ""Subway Therapy
column7: the installation lining the underground walls beneath Manhattan's Union Square was the idea of artist Matthew ""Levee"" Chavez.

column1: The last couple days have been stressful and I wanted to provide people with an opportunity to engage in a small and easy way
column2: he wrote in the magazine Quartz.Anyone can post a note
column3: and more than 10
column4: 000 people have
column5: Chavez wrote on Instagram. Democrat Hillary Clinton bested Trump 79 percent to 18 percent in New York City.

column1: Writers of the sticky notes took varied approaches. Some pledged political action
column2: saying ""Vote in 2018"" and ""I will do my part to change this!""A blue sticky note quotes novelist Zadie Smith on the subject of despair
column3: and a pink one quotes Jesus' Sermon on the Mount: ""Blessed are the meek
column4: for they shall inherit the earth.""New York's Democratic governor
column5: Andrew Cuomo
column6: struck a pro-immigrant message
column7: posting a note with lines from the Emma Lazarus poem that appear on the Statue of Liberty: ""Give me your tired
column9: your huddled masses yearning to be free... I lift my lamp beside the golden door.""

column1: The defiant stance expressed in the notes is the right message for New Yorkers to send
column2: said waitress Caitlin Cherry
column4: as she paused to look at them.""I'm happy that people who are visiting can see that not all Americans want this
column5: she said.In a separate sign of protest
column6: three apartment buildings on Manhattan's Upper West Side are dropping the name Trump Place and will be known by their addresses
column7: the trade publication Real Deal reported
column8: citing an email to tenants from landlord Equity Residential. Some tenants had circulated a petition requesting the change.      (Reporting by David Ingram; Editing by Dan Grebler)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-house-democrats-idUSKBN13A23S	House Democrats mull Pelosi leadership future	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON U.S. House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi agreed on Tuesday to postpone the party's leadership elections until Nov. 30 amid discontent among some rank-and-file Democrats over her leadership style
column2: according to sources familiar with closed-door discussions.Democrats in the House of Representatives now are scheduled to vote on Nov. 30 on whether to renew Pelosi's long-held position as Democratic leader for another two years. Other Democratic house leadership jobs also will be up for a vote.No other Democrat has come forward to challenge Pelosi
column3: although at least one is weighing what likely would be an uphill bid to dethrone the liberal California Democrat.House Democrats gathered behind closed doors to assess what went wrong in the Nov. 8 elections that swept Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump into power and allowed Republicans to retain their majorities in both houses
column4: although slightly smaller ones than in the past two years.One senior House Democratic aide described Tuesday's meeting as being unusually contentious as members grappled with how the Democratic Party should rebuild following last week's election losses
column5: with some wanting new blood in leadership.""After every single election cycle
column6: she (Pelosi) says things are going to change"" in how she interacts with the caucus
column7: the aide said characterizing lawmakers' concerns. ""But then
column8: she doesn't do anything different. It's the same inside circle"" surrounding her.Democratic aides and a lawmaker said Pelosi made the announcement on the new date for party elections ""after protracted discussion"" in the meeting. The elections had been expected to take place on Thursday in preparation for Congress convening on Jan. 3.""We've been through hell
column10: according to a Democratic aide who was in the room but spoke on condition of anonymity. ""And it's only going to get worse as he (Trump) makes his appointments and we have this fight. But we have to see it as an opportunity.""

column1: DISMAYED DEMOCRATS
Pelosi
column2: who has been the House Democrats' leader for 14 years and speaker of the House part of that time
column3: said she did not care when the election was.""I do care that we have the strongest possible leadership at the table
column4: whoever that may be
column5: she said.

column1: Representative Seth Moulton and other Democrats dismayed by the national election results had urged Pelosi to postpone the leadership vote.""As we begin the 115th Congress
column2: House Democrats must take the time to reflect on the message the American people sent us last Tuesday
column3: Moulton said in a statement after the caucus.""Delaying the vote on leadership positions is the necessary first step to have that conversation
column4: he said. ""The American people cried out last week and we've got to listen.""Representative Tim Ryan
column6: is weighing a run against Pelosi
column8: Ryan's spokesman Michael Zetts said on Monday.

column1: He is concerned that if changes aren't made we will be in the political wilderness for many years to come
column2: Zetts said.   Ryan has been in the House since 2003.A Democratic lawmaker who declined to be named said Ryan would represent a new generation.""I think a lot of us feel the landscape has changed
column3: he said. ""We need people who can learn new tricks and not do things the way they have been done that last 20 or 30 years.""But Representative Steve Israel
column4: a member of House Democratic leadership and who is retiring from Congress at year's end
column5: said: ""There is nobody who could have led House Democrats who would have had a different outcome"" in last week's presidential and congressional elections.""This was not about Nancy Pelosi
column6: Israel told MSNBC. ""This was about a national Democratic strategy and message that simply did not tap into the unprecedented anxieties of middle-class voters."" (Reporting by Susan Cornwell and Richard Cowan; Writing by Susan Heavey; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama and Bill Trott)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-mexico-idUSKBN13A2OB	Mexico president to show 'pragmatism' dealing with Trump	"
MEXICO CITY Mexico will need to show ""enormous pragmatism"" in its dealings with Donald Trump's government
column2: President Enrique Pena Nieto said on Tuesday
column3: as his administration prepares to seek common ground on trade and immigration issues.Mexico is on tenterhooks awaiting the accession of Trump to the U.S. presidency because of his repeated threats on the campaign trail to impose tariffs on Mexican-made goods and seal the country off behind a massive border wall.Acknowledging that Trump's victory had generated some uncertainty
column4: Pena Nieto reiterated his government would pursue dialogue with the next U.S. government to reach agreements.""We'll have to work with enormous pragmatism to agree what's useful and convenient for Mexico and for the whole of North America
column5: he told a business summit in the central city of Puebla
column6: Mexican headquarters of German carmaker Volkswagen (VOWG_p.DE).

column1: The Mexican president added that his government was committed to providing macroeconomic stability for investors
column2: listing a flexible exchange rate
column3: central bank independence and a solid banking system among the key planks of his pledge.Concern has been widespread among business leaders and officials in Mexico that Trump could follow through on threats to abandon the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) if he cannot renegotiate it in the United States' interests.

column1: Struck between the United States
column2: Mexico and Canada
column3: NAFTA took effect in 1994 and has been the cornerstone of Mexican international trade policy. Mexico sends four-fifths of its goods exports to the United States.

column1: Still
column2: Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo believes Trump will not back out of NAFTA
column3: and has said Mexico could add new chapters to the deal to update it. (Reporting by Dave Graham; Editing by Lisa Shumaker)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-lgbt-texas-idUSKBN13A2NR	Texas eyes 'women's privacy act' that critics say targets transgender people	"
By Jon Herskovitz
| AUSTIN
column2: Texas

column1: AUSTIN
column2: Texas Texas plans to introduce a measure next year aimed at protecting women in bathrooms and locker rooms
column3: a move that has raised concerns of activists who say the legislation is really an attempt to discriminate against transgender people.The office of Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick said on Tuesday that a state senator will file the so-called ""Women's Privacy Act"" for consideration in the session that starts in January.Patrick's office did not have any details of the bill
column4: but the Republican lieutenant governor has been a supporter of only allowing access to facilities such as bathrooms based on gender at birth rather than the gender with which a person identifies.North Carolina in March became the first state to enact a law that restricts bathroom access for transgender people. The law prompted a federal civil rights lawsuit and has been blamed for hundreds of millions of dollars in economic losses and the relocation of major sporting events from the state.

column1: Patrick
column2: one of the most powerful forces in the Texas legislature and a supporter of President-elect Donald Trump
column3: called the measure in Texas one of his top priorities.""Starting in 2017
column4: we will have a friend in the White House who was clearly elected because the people of this country believe in the conservative principles that have guided the way we govern in Texas
column5: Patrick said in a statement on Monday.

column1: Patrick has been an opponent of policies under President Barack Obama administration's allowing transgender students to use the bathrooms of their choice
column2: saying the guidelines represented federal overreach and could allow for sexual predators to attack women.Lesbian
column3: gay
column4: bisexual and transgender advocacy groups say the current White House policies protect transgender students from discrimination and dismiss the safety concerns as rubbish.

column1: It is a total misnomer because the legislation has nothing to do protecting women's privacy
column2: said Chuck Smith
column3: executive director of Equality Texas
column4: a leading LGBT civil rights group in the state. ""The purpose of the legislation is to allow discrimination against transgender children and adults.""Texas business leaders
column5: a base of support for the Republican party
column6: in October warned lawmakers in the Republican-dominated statehouse that measures targeting the LGBT community would hurt the state's $1.8 trillion-a-year economy and make it difficult for employers to attract talent for crucial industries. (Reporting by Jon Herskovitz; Editing by Colleen Jenkins and Alan Crosby)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-health-idUSKBN13A2NE	Georgia congressman being eyed for top Trump health post: Politico	"
WASHINGTON Republican Representative Tom Price of Georgia is under consideration to be secretary of health and human services during a Trump administration
column2: Politico reported on Tuesday
column3: citing unnamed sources.Price
column4: the chairman of the House Budget Committee
column5: had endorsed Donald Trump's candidacy in May. The congressman has been a leading voice among Republicans pushing to repeal President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law.

column1: (Reporting by Timothy Ahmann; Editing by Eric Walsh)"
